Award.AwardTitle: Western US Center Planning Grant for Lasers+Photonics Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Jobs in lasers, precision optics, camera systems, photonics, and other technical areas that employ the science of light are essential aspects of our nation's technical competitiveness. The results of a recent national survey of photonics industries in the US conducted by the Advanced Technological Education (ATE) National Center, OP-TEC, showed that, in the Western US, companies currently employ nearly 5000 photonics technicians, and projected a need for over 1100 additional technicians over the five-year period following the survey. Irvine Valley College (IVC) is leveraging an NSF award in photonics that has led to the development of for-credit courses and an Associates' Degree program in Laser and Photonics Technology to recruit both additional industry and educational partners. Together the partners will develop a plan for a Regional Center in Photonics in the western US to respond to industry need for photonics technicians.

This planning effort brings together industry and educational partners from the states of California, Oregon, Washington, Arizona, Nevada, Utah, Idaho, Montana and Wyoming to develop a comprehensive plan for a Regional Center in Optics and Photonics that would prepare students for entry-level technical positions in the industry. IVC will continue to work with the ATE National Center, OP-TEC, during the planning process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Irvine Valley College (IVC) has augmented participation in its two-year Associate in Science (AS) program in Laser and Photonics Technology, in both student enrollment and industrial participation. The Laser Technology Program continues to train successfully students to have applied, globally competitive STEM skills, and these students have earned gainful employment immediately upon graduation with our industrial partners. We have placed our graduates in technician positions at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Newport, Alcon and Diverse Optics, to name a few collaborative organizations.

IVC has established itself as a Western-Region leader among the two-year technical colleges that specialize in precision optics, photonics, and lasers education. Even though the NSF has discontinued its regional Centers programs, which this grant was intended to foster, we intend to persevere and mentor our western-regional partner colleges into the foreseeable future. With our many industrial partners, we continue to create pathways to employment via four fundamental optics courses. We continue to test and improve these four courses, two of which we wrote directly under the guidance of OP-TEC and our industrial partners. Our program educates two- college students and veterans who are seeking new careers, employed technicians who are looking to rebrand themselves in the workplace, and students who intend to earn four-year university degrees, where they will, sadly, likely not have gained the hands-on laboratory experience that they will in our laboratory classroom. Many more students have improved their status at their current technical job, attending our classes after work hours, while still employed. We even have educated a few advanced high school students who have ambition to these educational paths. As with previous grants, we help develop skills of students who are dedicated to careers in science and technology, but lack the academic preparation or financial resources to achieve a four-year engineering degree. Our hands-on education in optical technology is motivating and applied—it leads directly to a rewarding career in the technical workforce.

We continue to work with industry to continually upgrade our existing curricula and the laboratory experiences for our students. We have the flexibility and interest to make relevant changes to our curricula based on our partners’ feedback and equipment donations, so our continually improved photonics courses feature the skills most desired by the optics industry. Well before we began receiving NSF funding in 2013, we promoted public literacy about the science of light by hosting educational outreach and open-house events that showcase to the general public and, in particular high school students who are perspective Laser Tech students. Once again, we have achieved the goals of our NSF grant as described herein from the perspective of our peers in academia and industry, and, most importantly, our employed graduates. IVC remains well-prepared to lead technician-level education in the lasers, photonics, and precision optics technologies in the Western US, as we will with our newly funded NSF grant, Optics, Photonics, and Lasers Technical Education Curriculum Development (grant 1801019).
